xxl.core.cursors.mappers

Class Mapper<I,E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • xxl.core.cursors.AbstractCursor<E>
      • xxl.core.cursors.mappers.Mapper<I,E>
  • Type Parameters:
    I - the type of the elements consumed by this iteration.
    E - the type of the elements returned by this mapped iteration.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Iterator<E>, Cursor<E>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    Mapper

    public class Mapper<I,E>
extends AbstractCursor<E>
    A mapper invokes a given mapping function on an array of input iterations. The mapping function is applied to n input iterations at the same time, that means a n-dimensional function is called and its arguments are the elements of each input iteration (an array storing one element per input iteration). The result of this mapping is an array storing the results of the different functions that is returned by the mapper. Also a partial input is allowed with the intention to apply the mapping function on less than n arguments.

    Note: When the given input iteration only implements the interface Iterator it is wrapped to a cursor by a call to the static method wrap. Additionally some mapping functions are supplied in the class Functions.

    Example usage (1): 

         Mapper<Integer, Integer> mapper = new Mapper<Integer, Integer>(
         new Function;Integer, Integer>() {
             public Integer invoke(Integer[] arguments) {
                 return arguments[0] * 2;
             }
         },
         new Enumerator(21)
     );
 
     mapper.open();
 
     while (mapper.hasNext())
         System.out.print(mapper.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
 
     mapper.close();
    This mapper maps the given numbers of the enumerator with range 0,...,20 concerning the above defined function 
         f : x → 2*x.
    The function is applied on each element of the given enumerator, therefore the following output is printed to the output stream: 
         0; 2; 4; 6; 8; 10; ... ; 36; 38; 40;
    But pay attention that the function's invoke method gets an object array as parameter!

    Example usage (2): 

         HashGrouper<Integer> hashGrouper = new HashGrouper<Integer>(
         new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
             public Integer invoke(Integer next) {
                 return next % 5;
             }
         },
         new Enumerator(21)
     );
 
     hashGrouper.open();
 
     Cursor<Integer>[] cursors = (Cursor<Integer>[])new Object[5];
     for (int i = 0; hashGrouper.hasNext(); i++)
         cursors[i] = hashGrouper.next();
     
     mapper = new Mapper<Integer, Integer>(
         cursors,
         new Function<Integer, Integer>() {
             public Integer invoke(Integer[] arguments) {
                 return Cursors.minima(new ArrayCursor<Integer>(arguments)).getFirst();
             }
         }
     );
 
     mapper.open();
 
     while (mapper.hasNext())
         System.out.print(mapper.next() + "; ");
     System.out.flush();
     
     mapper.close();
     hashGrouper.close();
    This example uses the a hash-grouper to partition the delivered numbers of the input enumerator. For further information see HashGrouper. The buckets of the hash-map used by the hash-grouper are stored in the cursor list cursors. Then a new mapper is created that maps this cursor array to the first element of its contained minima. Therefore the static method minima is used returning a linked list, where the getFirst method is applied. For the first call to next the cursor array contains the integer objects with value 0,...,4, namely the first element of each bucket. The returned minimum is 0. The next call to this method returns the minimum of 5,...,10, namely the second element in each bucket. So the output of this use case is: 
         0; 5; 10; 15;
    See Also:
    Iterator, Cursor, AbstractCursor

    • Constructor Detail

      • Mapper

        public Mapper(Function<? super I,? extends E> function,
              boolean allowPartialInput,
              Iterator<? extends I>... iterators)
        Creates a new mapper using an input iteration array and a user defined function to map the elements. The flag allowPartialInput defines whether the function can be used with a lower dimension than iterators.length. Every iterator to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor.
        Parameters:
        iterators - the input iterations.
        function - the function used to map the input-elements to an output-element.
        allowPartialInput - true if the function can be applied to less than one element of each input iterator.

      • Mapper

        public Mapper(Function<? super I,? extends E> function,
              Iterator<? extends I>... iterators)
        Creates a new mapper using the given input iteration array and user defined function to map the elements. Every iterator given to this constructor is wrapped to a cursor and no partial input is allowed.
        Parameters:
        iterators - the input iterations.
        function - the function used to map the input-elements to an output-element.

    • Method Detail

      • open

        public void open()
        Opens the mapper, i.e., signals the cursor to reserve resources, open input iterations, etc. Before a cursor has been opened calls to methods like next or peek are not guaranteed to yield proper results. Therefore open must be called before a cursor's data can be processed. Multiple calls to open do not have any effect, i.e., if open was called the cursor remains in the state opened until its close method is called.

        Note, that a call to the open method of a closed cursor usually does not open it again because of the fact that its state generally cannot be restored when resources are released respectively files are closed.

        Specified by:
        open in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        open in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • close

        public void close()
        Closes the mapper. Signals the mapper to clean up resources, close input iterations, etc. After a call to close calls to methods like next or peek are not guarantied to yield proper results. Multiple calls to close do not have any effect, i.e., if close was called the mapper remains in the state "closed".
        Specified by:
        close in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        close in class AbstractCursor<E>

      • hasNextObject

        protected boolean hasNextObject()
        Returns true if the iteration has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next or peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)

        This method returns true if all input iterations have more elements or if at least one input iteration has more elements and partial input is allowed.

        Specified by:
        hasNextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the mapper has more elements.

      • nextObject

        protected E nextObject()
        Computes the next element to be returned by a call to next or peek.

        A new object array arguments with length size() is assigned and filled with the next elements of the input iterations or null, if the next element of such an input iteration does not exist. Then the mapping function is applied and the next element to be returned by the mapper is returned.

        Specified by:
        nextObject in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        the next element in the iteration.

      • remove

        public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
        Removes from the underlying data structure the last element returned by the mapper (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek and removes the element returned by this method. Note, that between a call to next and remove the invocation of peek or hasNext is forbidden. The behaviour of a cursor is unspecified if the underlying data structure is modified while the iteration is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.

        Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

        Specified by:
        remove in interface Iterator<E>
        Specified by:
        remove in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        remove in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next or peek method.
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by the cursor.

      • supportsRemove

        public boolean supportsRemove()
        Returns true if the remove operation is supported by the mapper. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsRemove in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsRemove in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the remove operation is supported by the mapper, otherwise false.

      • reset

        public void reset()
           throws UnsupportedOperationException
        Resets the mapper to its initial state such that the caller is able to traverse the underlying data structure again without constructing a new cursor (optional operation). The modifications, removes and updates concerning the underlying data structure, are still persistent.

        Note, that this operation is optional and might not work for all cursors.

        Specified by:
        reset in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        reset in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if the reset operation is not supported by the mapper.

      • supportsReset

        public boolean supportsReset()
        Returns true if the reset operation is supported by the mapper. Otherwise it returns false.
        Specified by:
        supportsReset in interface Cursor<E>
        Overrides:
        supportsReset in class AbstractCursor<E>
        Returns:
        true if the reset operation is supported by the mapper, otherwise false.
